bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, December 30, 1921

div1.p: Noguchi informs Carter of the death, by yellow fever, of Cross - one of Noguchi's laboratory assistants. Cross had been sent to Mexico without being properly immunized. Noguchi openly questions the actions of the doctors who attended to Cross in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, December 30, 1921
div1.opener:
Answered
Jan 3/21
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
December 30, 1921.
(Confidential)
Dear General Carter:-
div1.p:
Knowing how deeply you have
been interested in recent development
in yellow fever research, I am writing
to you certain data connected with
Dr Cross's unfortunate death which occurred
on Dec. 26, this year. Dr Cross was a
Ph. D. and not an M. D.; had some training
in bacteriology and pathology at the Johns
Hopkins. He was engaged by the International
Health Board and sent to my laboratory
to learn special technics for yellow fever
bacteriology. He spent several months with
me and was sent down to Mexico on
November 23. He received rather a short
notice to catch the boat and had not
had enough time to get the vaccination.
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(2)
He managed to receive one injection, however,
on the day he sailed (Nov. 23, 1921), and was
to receive another on November 26 while on
the sea. Somehow, he landed on Vera
Cruz without the second injection, on Dec. 2,
namely 10 days from the first injection. He
received an injection on Dec. 3, intended apparently
to take the place of that which he missed on Nov. 26.
Of course, this injection cancould not take the place
of that he neglectedmissed, because the effect of the
first was already partly in force and the
introduction of the second injection simply neutralized
all whatever protective substances that had developed from the first injection.
Not only that, butit also produced a state of
weakened resistance, so-called the negative
phase of immunity, which usually lasts
several days or perhaps 10 days. In order
to establish the immunity it is usually
necessary to give another injection of vaccine
within a period of from 3 to 6 days. In
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(3)
other words, the process of vaccination must be
done over once more. Cross should have
received another injection on Dec. 6th or 7th and
should have waited, at least, 10 days longer before
considering himself reasonably protected. But,
(he failed to observe this rule) and wentwas sent
to Tuxtepec on Dec. 7, 1921, just during
the negative phase of the reaction. Dr White
and Dr Caldwell accompanied him on that trip,
but on Dec. 9th both returned to Vera Cruz,
leaving Cross in Tuxtepec alone. Tuxtepec
is a small town with no railroad connection,
lying about 100 miles from Vera Cruz and is
reached by horse back and river boat. While
Drs White and Caldwell were still in Tuxtepec
Cross made autopsy, on Dec. 8, on a
suspicious case, but they believed the finding
to be negative at that time. Anyhow,
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(4)
Cross was reported ill to Dr Caldwell on
Dec. 21 (?) and the latter reached Cross's
bedside on Dec. 22. Cross was attended
by a Tuxtepec physician by name of Dr Diaz
from December 19th to 22nd and according to Dr Caldwells' telegram neither he
nor Dr Diaz realized the nature of the disease,
until diagnosed by Dr Caldwell on Dec. 22
(according to Dr Caldwell's telegram). Dr
Caldwell did not bring any serum with
him and none was available in Tuxtepec.
On Dec. 23 Cross was brought back to
Vera Cruz (100 miles on horse back, river
boat, etc.) and placed under the care of
Drs Caldwell, Loyo, and “associates” in the
“best hospital” in Vera Cruz. No serum was
administered because the disease was too
far advanced in stage (according to Dr
Caldwell, 5 days already). On Dec. 26,
the temperature was 38°C., pulse 110, resp. 30,
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(5)
and 300 a. urine was passed by Catheter. He died at
12.20 p. m. All these details werehave been obtained
from Dr Caldwell by me through telegraphic
communications since Dec. 25. I had
no news of Cross's illness until that day
and the announcement of his death was
received in the afternoon of Dec. 26

Some side lights on the case are
thrown by Cross's daily letters to his wife
in New York. Cross slept under mosquito
net all the time and never remembered
of being ever bitten by any mosquito. He was able
to write until the afternoon of Dec. 19th and mentioned how
well he was feeling and that he was rather
annoyed by not having seen a single
case of yellow fever yet. Of course,
it is possible to have a letter dated a
day wrong, ahead or behind, especially in
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(6)
a way out of place like Tuxtepec, but if
his dates are correct, Cross must have been
taken ill on Dec. 20th or during the night
of Dec. 19th; consequently onwas in his 3rd day
of illness when Caldwell reached to his
bedside on Dec. 22. Serum could have
been of some value if administered on
that date. Unfortunately, none washad been
availablebrought!. (There was a sufficient
amount of serum in Dr Caldwell's care
at Vera Cruz as we made in certain
by a Cable inquiry before Cross sailed from
my laboratory). Somehow, Cross was
taken by Caldwell back to Vera Cruz. It
is still a mystery to me why Cross was
carried about by 100 miles on his 4th day of
yellow fever. I would appreciate very
much if you can give me some tangible
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
(7)
explanation for such an action by any
physician. I always believed neat
quickness was one of the most important
factors in the treatment of yellow fever.

Thus, contrary to the press dispatches
from Vera Cruz, that Cross was immediately
taken back to Vera Cruz and given every
known means to save him, we possess
a few cold facts which must be
carefully considered before we justify
the press announcement. Certainly, neither
the vaccine nor the serum has been given
any chance to show itself in this most
lamentable incidence in the history of
yellow fever.

I am very sorry, indeed, for Cross and
his devoted wife and hope to get more
light when histhe data on his case arrive.

THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK

In the future, I must counsel the organizers
of any yellow fever expedition not to send
a lone laboratory man into an infected
area, but at least, two “medical men”
should be in the party. They ought to
be together all the time. Besides, I
believe that even a laboratory man should
be an M. D. to join the expedition.

I have dealt in great length and must
apologize for taking up so much of your time.

With my sincere thanks for
your past considerations and in
great admiration of your work,
div1.closer:
Yours faithfully Hideyo Noguchi
C1
B22
P. S. It was understood from the beginning
that the personal protective measures by means
of the vaccination are only supplementary
to screening against the stegomyia
bites. But, why can not this process be
adopted as a routine just as much as
screening is done where there is a danger?
As to the serum it seems reasonable to
think that any future expedition on yellow
fever should be provided with it and use it
on any case that may arise. It has not
done any harm and showed decided
reduction of mortality then employed within
3 days of the disease. If you agree with
my views I wish you would recommend
such a step to the Board. If this were in
force, Cross would not have been alone and
the serum would have been with him
anywhere he found himself.
H. N.
